title: Unrealized Gains Tax on Crypto: The New 36% Law Explained (What HODLers Must Know)

So, what does this law  actually do? Well, starting on the 1st of January   2028, Dutch residents will be taxed at a flat rate  of 36% on the actual returns of their investments.   And here's the kicker. for assets like stocks,  bonds, and uh yes, cryptocurrency, actual return   includes capital growth even if you haven't  sold. It's a   clear double standard that punishes liquid assets  and innovation. Now, you might be wondering, why   on earth would they do this? Well, to be blunt,  they didn't really want to. Even the lawmakers   who voted yes admitted this isn't ideal. They are  basically desperate to plug a€ 2.3 billion euro   annual revenue hole left after the Dutch Supreme  Court ruled their previous tax system was illegal.   So, they rushed this through as a quote bridge  solution, a very expensive portfolio destroying   bridge. And if   it works there, meaning it raises enough money  without causing a total economic collapse,   you can bet other finance ministers will be  taking notes. But here is the real nightmare   scenario for crypto investors. It's called the  liquidity death spiral. Imagine you hold Bitcoin   worth $100,000. You bought it cheap, maybe  at $20,000. Under a 36% unrealized gains tax,   you have an $80,000 gain. And that means you owe  roughly $28,800 in taxes. But uh you haven't sold   a bitcoin. You don't have $20,000 in cash lying  around. So what do you do? You have to sell   some Bitcoin to pay the tax. Now multiply this  across millions of investors. Every tax season,   everyone is forced to sell assets at the same  time to pay taxes on paper profits. This mass   selling drives down the price. And because the  price is dropping, liquidity dries up. It creates   a feedback loop where the tax itself triggers the  crash it was designed to capture. Sure, you  can carry those losses forward to future years,   but that doesn't help you pay the bill due now. It  is mathematically ruinous. Now, before we get into   how you can protect yourself from this, and there  are ways, I want to mention something important   about staying informed. Policies like this can pop  up overnight, and if you aren't paying attention,   they can wreck your strategy. And that is why we  have the Coinbau Telegram channel. So, sign up today   using the link down below or scanning this QR code  over here. Okay, back to taxes. Now, you might be   thinking, if they pass this law, I'll just leave.  Easier said than done. The Dutch proposal includes   something called a quote protective assessment  or conserv. Basically, if you try to immigrate,   they calculate the tax on your unrealized gains  right then and there. It's an exit tax. They might   let you defer payment, but the debt hangs over  you indefinitely. It's capital controls disguised   as tax policy. And history shows us exactly  how this ends. In the 1970s, the UK had a top   tax rate of 98% on investment income. The result,  the brain drain. Anyone with talent or money left   the country. France had the ISF wealth tax.   It caused an exodus of 42,000 millionaires and 35  billion euros in capital flight. They repealed it   in 2017. The lesson is clear. Wealth is mobile. If  you try to tax it before it's realized, it leaves.   The Netherlands is set to learn this lesson the  hard way. So, what are sophisticated investors   doing to prepare? Because you can bet they aren't  just sitting there waiting to get wrecked. First,   we are seeing a migration to crypto friendly  jurisdictions. Portugal used to be the go-to   with zero tax. It forces you to sell the very thing   you are trying to build. But here's the silver  lining, guys. Capital goes to where it is treated   best. The   choice is coming sooner than you might think. You  need to look at your portfolio and ask yourself.   If my country passed this law tomorrow, would I  be solvent? summary_hu: A holland parlament által jóváhagyott új törvény 36%-os adót vezet be a meg nem valósult nyereségekre, ami 2028-tól lép életbe. Ez a jogszabály arra kényszeríti a kriptovaluta-tulajdonosokat, hogy eladjanak eszközöket a befizetendő adó miatt, ami jelentős piaci zavart okozhat. A törvény kivételt képez a valós ingatlanok és induló vállalkozások részvényei számára, ami kettős mércét alkalmaz. A nemzetközi adópolitikák trendjei és a költségvetési hiányok következtében a globális kriptovaluta-piacra is kihatással lehet. A törvények szigorodása arra ösztönözheti a befektetőket, hogy más országokba költözzenek, mint például Portugáliába vagy az Egyesült Arab Emírségekbe, ahol kedvezőbb adózási környezet van.
summary_en: The new law passed by the Dutch Parliament imposes a 36% tax on unrealized gains, effective from 2028. This regulation forces cryptocurrency holders to sell their assets to pay taxes, potentially causing significant market disruptions. The law exempts real estate and startup shares, creating a double standard. The international trend of tightening tax policies and budget deficits can also impact the global cryptocurrency market. Stricter laws may incentivize investors to relocate to countries like Portugal or the UAE, where the tax environment is more favorable.
